awd_titl_txt: NCS-FO: Spatial Intelligence for Swarms Based on Hippocampal Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project brings together theories of brain functions and principles of robotic swarm control to develop smarter swarms and to better understand the neural processes underlying spatial representations, navigation, and planning. Our world is constantly changing, and mammals have evolved the cognitive ability to plan new paths or new strategies as needed. By contrast, autonomous robots are less robust, and often have difficulty operating in complex, changing environments. This research project is grounded in the idea that individual robots in a group can be thought of analogously to neurons in an animal's brain, which interact with one another to form dynamic patterns that collectively signal locations in space and time relative to brain rhythms. This distribution of information across space and time will enable a new paradigm of swarm control, in which swarms automatically adapt to changes in the world in the same way that a rat knows which detour to take around an unexpected obstacle. Unmanned robots are rapidly becoming a crucial technology for commercial, military, and scientific endeavors throughout the nation and across the globe. Critical future applications such as disaster relief and search & rescue will require intelligent spatial coordination among many robots spread over large geographical areas. This project will advance neural swarming as a control paradigm for this next generation of technological development. Additionally, this project will drive an extensive science, technology, engineering, and mathematics education program to bring the concepts of spatial intelligence, hippocampal information processing, and swarm control to high school students to improve literacy in neuroscience and robotics.

The project's goal is to build a unified framework for self-organized, bottom-up control of spatial task planning that synergistically advances theoretical neuroscience and swarm control paradigms. In the project's brain-to-swarm metaphor, neurons are autonomous agents, spikes are agent-based phase signals, and emergent circuit activity is emergent swarm behavior. The approach targets neural computations in hippocampal circuits and related systems that may contribute to online dynamic replanning. The research thrusts comprise data-driven dynamical network and point-process models of neural activity sequences, mathematical analysis of swarming dynamics using matrix manifolds, and autonomous systems simulations in realistic virtual environments. The project will advance understanding of emergent hippocampal dynamics and autonomous methods for dynamic replanning, motivating new research in distributed control. The project's framework may enable mass-scalability for large, agile swarms of simple robotic agents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Animals and many-robot groups must solve common problems to navigate complex and uncertain environments. To advance our understanding of how brain solves these spatial problems, we investigated models of spatial learning dynamics in neural circuit by translating theoretical mechanisms in the mammalian hippocampus and adjacent structures to the domain of autonomous multiagent swarms. We developed a brain-inspired framework for swarming models, called 'NeuroSwarms', based on properties of rhythmic neural coding that we discovered in analyses of electrophysiological single-unit recordings from the lateral septum in foraging rats. We characterized a novel class of neurons, which we called 'phaser cells', each with a distinct phase, or temporal offset with respect to a shared ongoing oscillation known as the hippocampal theta rhythm. Our models of phaser cells demonstrated a robust collective code for spatial trajectories of simulated rodent foraging. In the NeuroSwarms framework, we found that complex collective spatial behaviors emerged when we introduced an analogous coding scheme to the agent controller models. Specifically, we assigned a periodic phase variable to each agent that was governed by inputs from the environment and nearby agents. By comparing these phase-states between pairs of agents, the controller modulates the degree of attraction or repulsion between them, leading to complex, spontaneous behaviors that proved capable of solving a variety of spatially distributed tasks including navigation. 

NeuroSwarms behaviors included swarming, milling, patroling, aggegation, spatial coverage, multireward navigation, and cue-driven clustering. Moreover, swarming behaviors were autonomously flexible and reconfigurable across spatial and temporal scales with respect to the geometric boundaries of complex environments. Our NeuroSwarms framework demonstrated that our analogy of neurons-as-agents and networks-as-groups enabled well-known learning rules from neuroscience to efficiently control high-level spatial and navigational behaviors in simulated agent groups. A key insight of NeuroSwarms' navigational capacities was that generalization to new environments was achieved by simple adaptation of dynamical parameters, without the need for large amounts of training data or calculating credit-assignment updates, as typically required by deep learning-based methods. The motion of NeuroSwarms is determined by a fast, flexible, and 'online' learning process. Thus, the findings and demonstrations accomplished by our project, including our principle of learning-as-motion in phase-coupled agents, establish a novel paradigm for resilient bottom-up control of autonomous swarming for navigation and other tasks in complex, uncertain, and/or changing environments. 

Our project became the basis of a symposium that we organized at the 6th Annual NIH BRAIN Investigators Meeting (June, 2020). Our symposium, moderated by a team member and featured six panelists including another team member, drew a live online audience of 500+ neuroscientists. The symposium was entitled "How can dynamical systems neuroscience reciprocally advance machine learning?":

https://www.labroots.com/webinar/symposium-1-dynamical-systems-neuroscience-reciprocally-advance-machine-learning (Labroots)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2jy1ENYHRAw (Labroots)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bMWTVhfjbEE (Team-Archived Copy)

Afterwards we proposed a commentary article to Nature Machine Intelligence, which subsequently invited a full perspective article regarding the intersection of neural dynamics and artificial intelligence. The manuscript, currently in revision at the journal, is available as a preprint:

Monaco JD, Rajan K, and Hwang GM. (2021). A brain basis of dynamical intelligence for AI and computational neuroscience. ArXiv Preprint. arxiv:2105.07284. https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.07284

Virtual conference talks about our project are available online:

Monaco JD. (Dec 1, 2021). Learning as swarming: Cognitive flexibility from the neural dynamics of phase-coupled attractor maps. Neuromatch Conference 4.0. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3mKkLksOyfk

Monaco JD. (Oct 29, 2020). Spatial theta-phase coding in the lateral septum: A theory of allocentric feedback during navigation. Neuromatch Conference 3.0. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WwYDMpD7j4Q

The source code for NeuroSwarms controller model implementation from our Biological Cybernetics paper (Monaco et al., 2020) is available here: 

Code Archive: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4281048

GitHub: https://github.com/jdmonaco/neuroswarms

The source code and preprocessed datasets for our modeling and analyses of septal 'phaser cell' recordings (from the lab of H.T. Blair, UCLA) are available here: 

Code Archive: https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.6072317.v1

Dataset: https://osf.io/psbcw/

To enhance the broader impact of our project, we developed, organized, and ran a STEM outreach program for high school students, featuring an interactive virtual training program at the intersection of neuroscience, robotics, and computer science. The highlight of this program was a four-day virtual microseminar, entitled "Swarming Powered by Neuroscience", conducted through presentations and interactive cloud-based videogame simulations. The microseminar was delivered by project team members serving as experts in neuroscience, mathematics, swarming, multi-agent robotics, and STEM education. A manuscript describing our outreach program and quantitative findings is being submitted to IEEE Integrated STEM Education Conference 2022; a preprint is available here:

Buckley E, Monaco JD, Schultz KM, Chalmers R, Hadzic A, Zhang K, Hwang GM, and Carr MD. (2021). An interdisciplinary approach to high school curriculum development: Swarming Powered by Neuroscience. ArXiv Preprint. arxiv:2109.05545. https://arxiv.org/abs/2109.05545

A study of methods for characterizing and optimizing neurodynamical models like NeuroSwarms is being submitted to a journal; a preprint is available here:

Hadzic A, Hwang GM, Zhang K, Schultz KM, and Monaco JD. (2021). Bayesian optimization of distributed neurodynamical controller models for spatial navigation. ArXiv Preprint. arxiv:2111.00599.https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.00599
